subject: Physics
expanded_description: Analysis of internal forces within systems of connected objects, including contact forces, tension in multi-object systems, and the distinction between internal and external forces. Focus on problem-solving strategies for determining forces between system components.
learning_objectives: Identify and analyze internal forces within systems
Distinguish between internal and external forces
Solve for internal tensions in multi-segment systems
Apply systematic methods to determine all internal forces

core_concept.principle: Internal forces are forces between components within a system, while external forces act on the system from outside. Internal forces always occur in equal and opposite pairs (Newton's Third Law) and cancel when considering the system as a whole. To determine internal forces, systems must be divided at the points of interest, and Newton's Laws applied to individual components.
core_concept.explanation: Understanding internal forces requires analyzing subsystems and recognizing that while internal forces don't affect the overall system motion, they determine how forces are distributed within the system and can cause internal stresses and deformations.

image.caption: Internal forces: Act between system components, cancel in overall system analysis

sections.introduction: The fundamental distinction between internal and external forces is crucial for proper system analysis. Internal forces determine how external forces are distributed within a system.

image.alt: Internal vs external forces in systems
image.caption: Force classification: External forces act on system boundary, internal forces act between components

key_concept.definition: External forces: Act on the system from outside its boundaries (gravity, applied pushes/pulls, friction with external surfaces). Internal forces: Act between components within the system (contact forces, tension in connecting strings, inter-molecular forces). Key property: $\sum \vec{F}_{internal} = 0$ for the entire system, so internal forces don't affect the center of mass motion.
key_concept.context: This distinction allows simplification of overall motion analysis while still enabling detailed internal force determination when needed.

image.alt: Classification of forces as internal or external
image.caption: Force classification: Depends on system boundary definition

classifications.value: Types of forces that act within systems
classifications.behavior: Different internal force types have different characteristics and mathematical descriptions

examples.explanation: Forces between touching objects, perpendicular (normal) and parallel (friction) components

image.caption: Contact forces: Normal and friction components at interfaces

examples.explanation: Pulling forces through strings, ropes, or rods connecting system components

image.caption: Internal tension: Transmits force between connected objects

classifications.note: Whether a force is internal or external depends on how the system boundary is defined

principles.statement: The classification of a force as internal or external depends entirely on how the system boundary is drawn. A force is internal if both the acting and receiving objects are within the system boundary, and external if either the acting or receiving object is outside the boundary
principles.application: Proper problem-solving requires clearly defining the system boundary before classifying forces and applying Newton's Laws
principles.example: For two blocks pushed together, the contact force between them is internal if considering both blocks as the system, but external if considering each block separately
principles.analogy: Like national borders - trade within a country is internal, while international trade is external

image.caption: System boundary: Determines whether forces are internal or external

worked_examples.title: Identifying Internal vs External Forces
worked_examples.problem: Two blocks (A and B) are pushed along a rough floor. Identify forces as internal or external when the system is: (a) Block A only, (b) Block B only, (c) Both blocks together.

step_by_step.explanation: External: weight, normal force from floor, friction with floor, push from hand, contact force from B. Internal: none (only one object)
External: weight, normal force, friction, contact force from A. Internal: none
External: weights, normal forces, friction forces, push from hand. Internal: contact force between A and B

worked_examples.final_answer: Contact force between blocks is internal only when both blocks are in the system
worked_examples.concept_applied: Force classification depends on system definition

image.caption: Force classification: Changes with system boundary definition

worked_examples.title: Internal Force Cancellation
worked_examples.problem: Two 2 kg blocks are pushed with 20 N force. Show that internal forces cancel when considering the system as a whole.

step_by_step.explanation: Contact force between blocks is now internal

step_by_step.step: List all forces on the system
step_by_step.explanation: External: 20 N push, friction forces, weights, normal forces. Internal: contact force pair F_AB and F_BA

step_by_step.step: Apply Newton's Third Law to internal forces
step_by_step.explanation: F_AB = -F_BA, so they sum to zero
ΣF_external = (m_A + m_B)a, internal forces don't appear

worked_examples.final_answer: Internal contact forces cancel: F_AB + F_BA = 0
worked_examples.concept_applied: Internal force cancellation in system analysis

image.caption: Internal cancellation: Equal and opposite internal forces sum to zero

sections.introduction: Determining internal forces requires isolating subsystems and applying Newton's Laws to individual components, taking advantage of the fact that internal forces become external when the system is divided.

image.caption: Internal force analysis: Isolate subsystems to make internal forces external

key_concept.definition: To find internal forces: (1) Determine system acceleration using overall analysis, (2) Divide system at point of interest, making the internal force external to the subsystem, (3) Apply F=ma to the subsystem, (4) Solve for the unknown internal force. Common internal forces: Contact force F_contact between objects, Tension T in connecting strings, Normal force F_N at interfaces, Friction f between components.
key_concept.context: This systematic approach allows determination of forces at specific points within complex systems.

image.caption: Internal force method: Divide system and analyze subsystems

classifications.value: Different approaches for determining internal forces
classifications.behavior: Different methods work better for different system types and force determination goals

examples.explanation: Divide system at point of interest and analyze resulting subsystems separately

image.caption: Subsystem isolation: Makes internal forces accessible to analysis

examples.explanation: Imaginary cut through system reveals internal forces at that section

image.caption: Section cuts: Reveal internal forces at specific locations

classifications.note: The subsystem method is most general and works for all Newtonian mechanics problems

principles.statement: Internal forces transmit external forces through systems, distributing the applied loads among system components. The pattern of force transmission depends on system geometry, connection types, and mass distribution. Internal forces ensure that all components accelerate together according to their mass ratios
principles.application: This explains why different parts of a system experience different internal forces even when accelerating together
principles.example: When pushing two connected blocks, the front block experiences only the pushing force minus the contact force, while the back block experiences only the contact force
principles.analogy: Like a train - the locomotive pulls the first car, which pulls the second, and so on, with different tension forces in each coupling

image.caption: Force transmission: Internal forces distribute external loads through system

worked_examples.title: Contact Force Between Blocks
worked_examples.problem: Two blocks (m_A = 3 kg, m_B = 5 kg) are pushed with 40 N force on frictionless surface. Find the contact force between them.

step_by_step.step: Isolate block B (the one not being pushed directly)
step_by_step.explanation: Forces on B: contact force F_contact from A (only horizontal force)
F_contact = m_B a = 5 × 5 = 25 N
For A: 40 - F_contact = 3 × 5, F_contact = 25 N ✓

worked_examples.concept_applied: Subsystem isolation for contact force determination

image.caption: Contact force: Determined by analyzing less-massive object first

worked_examples.title: Internal Tension in Three-Mass System
worked_examples.problem: Three masses connected: m₁ = 2 kg, m₂ = 3 kg, m₃ = 4 kg, pulled with 36 N force. Find tension between m₁-m₂ and m₂-m₃.

step_by_step.explanation: a = F_total/(m₁ + m₂ + m₃) = 36/9 = 4 m/s²

step_by_step.step: Find T₂₃ (tension between m₂ and m₃)
step_by_step.explanation: Isolate m₃: T₂₃ = m₃a = 4 × 4 = 16 N

step_by_step.step: Find T₁₂ (tension between m₁ and m₂)
step_by_step.explanation: Isolate m₂ + m₃: T₁₂ = (m₂ + m₃)a = 7 × 4 = 28 N
For m₁: 36 - T₁₂ = 2 × 4, T₁₂ = 28 N ✓

sections.introduction: Real-world systems often involve complex internal force distributions, requiring sophisticated analysis techniques and understanding of how internal forces affect system behavior and design.

image.caption: Complex systems: Multiple internal forces with practical applications

key_concept.definition: Complex internal force scenarios include: Multi-segment structures with varying cross-sections, Systems with internal friction and constraints, Rotating systems with centripetal forces, Statically indeterminate systems, and Deformable bodies with stress distributions. Advanced methods: Method of joints for trusses, Shear and bending moment diagrams, Stress-strain relationships, Finite element analysis.
key_concept.context: These advanced applications demonstrate how internal force analysis extends beyond simple connected masses to real engineering systems.

image.caption: Advanced analysis: Methods for complex internal force determination

classifications.behavior: Different system types require specialized approaches beyond basic Newtonian mechanics

image.caption: Statically indeterminate: Cannot be solved by statics alone

examples.explanation: Internal forces cause deformations, which in turn affect force distribution

image.caption: Deformable bodies: Internal forces related to deformations

classifications.note: Complex systems may require numerical methods or advanced mechanical concepts beyond basic Newtonian analysis

principles.statement: In continuous bodies, internal forces are distributed as stress (force per unit area). The total internal force across a section equals the integral of stress over the area. For uniform stress: Internal force = Stress × Area. This relationship connects microscopic force distributions to macroscopic internal forces
principles.application: This principle allows calculation of whether materials will fail under load by comparing internal stresses to material strength limits
principles.example: For a rod in tension, the internal force is constant along the rod, but if the cross-sectional area varies, the stress changes accordingly
principles.analogy: Like water pressure in a pipe - the force on a section depends on both pressure and pipe diameter

image.caption: Stress relationship: Internal force distributed over area

worked_examples.title: Incline with Friction Internal Forces
worked_examples.problem: Two blocks (m_A = 4 kg, m_B = 6 kg) on 30° incline with μ = 0.2 between blocks and μ = 0.3 between block B and incline. Find internal friction force between blocks.

step_by_step.explanation: Net force parallel to incline = (m_A + m_B)g sinθ - f_kB, where f_kB = μ_kB(m_A + m_B)g cosθ

step_by_step.step: Isolate block A to find internal friction
step_by_step.explanation: For A: m_A g sinθ - f_AB = m_A a

worked_examples.final_answer: Internal friction force between blocks = 10.16 N

image.caption: Internal friction: Different friction coefficients create internal forces

worked_examples.title: Internal Forces in Elevator System
worked_examples.problem: Elevator (m = 500 kg) carries 3 people (70 kg each). Cable tension is 7500 N. Find internal normal force between floor and one person.

step_by_step.explanation: a = F_net/m_total = 542/710 = 0.763 m/s² upward
Forces on person: weight downward, normal force upward

common_misconceptions: Thinking internal forces affect overall system acceleration
Forgetting that internal forces occur in action-reaction pairs
Assuming all internal forces are equal in complex systems
Overlooking internal forces when drawing system free-body diagrams
summary: Internal forces act between components within a system, while external forces act on the system from outside. Key properties: internal forces always occur in equal and opposite pairs (Newton's Third Law), sum to zero for the entire system, and don't affect center of mass motion. To determine internal forces: (1) Find system acceleration, (2) Divide system at point of interest, (3) Apply F=ma to subsystem. Internal forces include contact forces, tension in connectors, and friction between components. Complex systems may involve statically indeterminate situations or deformable body mechanics requiring advanced analysis methods. Understanding internal forces is crucial for structural design and mechanical system analysis.
